sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving aqueous solutions
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between solid potassium hydroxide (KOH) and aqueous hydrochloric acid (HCl) to form aqueous potassium chloride (KCl) and liquid water (H2O)? Given the following balanced chemical equation:

KOH(s) + HCl(aq) → KCl(aq) + H2O(l)

Molar enthalpies of formation for KOH, HCl, KCl and H2O are -424.24 kJ/mol, -92.31 kJ/mol, -436.53 kJ/mol, and -285.83 kJ/mol respectively.
message_2:
To find the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

where ΔH° is the standard enthalpy change, and ΔHf° represents the standard molar enthalpies of formation for the products and reactants.

For the given reaction:

KOH(s) + HCl(aq) → KCl(aq) + H2O(l)

ΔH° = [ΔHf°(KCl) + ΔHf°(H2O)] - [ΔHf°(KOH) + ΔHf°(HCl)]

Substitute the given values:

ΔH° = [(-436.53 kJ/mol) + (-285.83 kJ/mol)] - [(-424.24 kJ/mol) + (-92.31 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = (-722.36 kJ/mol) - (-516.55 kJ/mol)

ΔH° = 205.81 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction between solid potassium hydroxide and aqueous hydrochloric acid to form aqueous potassium chloride and liquid water is 205.81 kJ/mol.
